https://archive.vn/vTndr  "Delhi Schools Closed After Yellow Alert  Delhi government shuts schools, colleges and other educational institutions until further orders"  "Odisha: Primary Classes To Resume In January  The Odisha government Tuesday announced that physical classes will resume for students of classes 1 to 5 from January 3 . The announcement was made by School and Mass Education Minister S R Dash a few hours after Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik directed officials to make preparations on war-footing to deal with a possible third wave of COVID-19 in the state. (PTI)|"  "West Bengal Schools, Colleges May Be Closed  West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee on Wednesday asked officials to review the overall COVID-19 situation in the state. Ms Banerjee, during an administrative review meeting at Sagar Island, also said that schools and colleges might be shut down for some time if the situation so demands.   "COVID-19 cases are on the rise... there are a few Omicron cases also. So, review the situation in the state. We may consider closing down schools and colleges for some time," the minister told officials at the meeting. (PTI)"

Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations. Please see below the US embassy link    https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Nepal banned large public gatherings and closed schools across the Himalayan nation for nearly three weeks (until January 29th) after a spike in coronavirus cases:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117201833/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-closes-schools-covid-19-cases-spike-2022-01-10/

Lockdown lifted but all kinds of public gatherings, such as political rallies and mass meetings, jatras and religious festivals with large gatherings of people, remain banned in Kathmandu Valley until further notification.  Kathmandu has allowed movie halls, nightclubs, dohori restaurants to reopen at 50 per cent capacity.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210903111134/https://thehimalayantimes.com/opinion/editorial-no-more-lockdown

There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to strict COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The Nepali authorities have imposed temporary restrictions to control the COVID-19 outbreak, including limiting public transport services. Non-essential services are partially closed, and restrictions may be introduced or extended at short notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117203348/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/coronavirus

Commercial flights are operating but with limited availability. The Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) has announced that all domestic flights have resumed, and strict COVID protocols are enforced. Operation of cargo flights, rescue flights, and evacuation flights will be carried out subject to special permission.  Please US embassy link last updated 04/10/21  https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     Effective September 24, all fully vaccinated foreigners arriving in Nepal via the immigration office at the airport or a land border can receive on-arrival visas. No quarantine required. Fully-vaccinated travellers travelling to Nepal must present the following documents:  1.Evidence of completion of a 14 day post-COVID-19 vaccination incubation period  2.COVID-19 negative PCR test report obtained within 72 hours of entry into Nepal    On-arrival visas at land border entries are not available to unvaccinated travelers. All unvaccinated and semi-vaccinated travelers must comply with the Government of Nepalâs 10-day quarantine mandate, which requires quarantine at a local hotel at their own cost. A PCR test must be completed and returned negative on 11th day before travelling within the country will be permitted. Such travelers must present the following documents:  1.COVID-19 negative PCR test report obtained within 72 hours of entering the country

According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has approved 5 vaccine (Astrazeneca, Stupnik V, Covaxin, Sinovac, Sinopharm). See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018181222/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    Government set to provide the booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine to those whoâve completed their vaccination at least 3 months ago; Health Minister Birodh Khatiwada has requested all eligible to get the booster dose; students aged 12-18 years will be given the COVID-19 shots in schools from January 2022; government is preparing to administer 200,000 doses of COVID-19 vaccine daily    According to MoH Nepal, as of late December 2021, 35,8% of the population (including children) have received the 1st dose and 30% are fully vaccinated. The schools were fully opened. From December, 17,2021 to January,02,2022, all schools were closed for an academic break. Schools resumed opening and students returned to schools on January,03,2022. Source: UNESCO global monitoring of schools closure due to COVID-19 interactive map  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220107192610/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

According to the recent updates on measures against COVID-19 released on December, 06,2021 and on January,05,2022, rules of varying degrees remain in effect nationwide. In cities with vaccination rates of over 60% restrictions on indoor dining, religious activities, and most public facilities are no longer in effect. However, localities remain subject to nationwide protocols. Stricter measures are ongoing in areas with vaccination rates of below 60%, public facilities can open with varying operating hours and capacity limits. Essential businesses can operate for 24 hours daily nationwide. The government prohibit unvaccinated people from entering public facilities, such as schools and shopping malls. Violators may be subject to fines and arrest. Local governments in some areas may implement enhanced curbs, such as tighter operating hours and capacity limits for public facilities, due to higher COVID-19 activity. Source: Garda World  Archived link:https://web.archive.org/web/20220109174844/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/552861/pakistan-authorities-suspend-most-travel-from-additional-international-locations-as-of-dec-6-update-63  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109175054/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/562991/pakistan-authorities-lift-travel-bans-modify-entry-testing-restrictions-as-of-jan-5-update-64

According to the recent updates on measures against COVID-19 released on December, 06,2021 and on January,05,2022, localities with vaccination rates of 40-60% and below 40% can allow gatherings of up to 500 and 300 people, respectively. Source: Garda World  Archived link:https://web.archive.org/web/20220109174844/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/552861/pakistan-authorities-suspend-most-travel-from-additional-international-locations-as-of-dec-6-update-63  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109175054/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/562991/pakistan-authorities-lift-travel-bans-modify-entry-testing-restrictions-as-of-jan-5-update-64

According to the recent updates on measures against COVID-19 released on December, 06,2021 and on January,05,2022, localities with vaccination rates of 40-60% and below 40% can allow gatherings of up to 500 and 300 people, respectively. Source: Garda World  Archived link:https://web.archive.org/web/20220109174844/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/552861/pakistan-authorities-suspend-most-travel-from-additional-international-locations-as-of-dec-6-update-63  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109175054/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/562991/pakistan-authorities-lift-travel-bans-modify-entry-testing-restrictions-as-of-jan-5-update-64

According to the recent updates on measures against COVID-19 released on December, 06,2021 and on January,05,2022, public transport vehicle can operate with up to 80% capacity. Source: Garda World  Archived link:https://web.archive.org/web/20220109174844/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/552861/pakistan-authorities-suspend-most-travel-from-additional-international-locations-as-of-dec-6-update-63  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109175054/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/562991/pakistan-authorities-lift-travel-bans-modify-entry-testing-restrictions-as-of-jan-5-update-64

There is no curfew in place. However, there are COVID-19 mitigation protocol in place to limit hours of operation and number of patrons. Government officials may implement lockdowns of street and neighbourhoods where COVID-19 outbreak occur. Source: US embassy in Pakistan  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109190300/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travels. Source: US embassy in Pakistan  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109190300/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

As of December,06,2021, the Pakistani government has added Croatia, Hungary, Ireland, Netherlands, Poland, Slovenia, Ukraine, and Vietnam to its Category C locations and suspended most travel from these countries due to concerns over a new COVID-19 variant (Omicron). Officials have earlier classified Botswana, Eswatini, Hong Kong, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, and South Africa, as category C locations. International travellers with recent travel history to these countries are not able to enter Pakistan. Returning Pakistani citizens from these countries only enter Pakistan in emergency cases. If they allowed to enter they must present a vaccination certificate, show a negative result from a PCR test taken within 48 hours before departure, take a rapid antigen test upon arrival, and quarantine at either their residence or designated facilities.   Travellers arriving by air from other countries must submit a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within 48 hours before arrival and a health declaration from online or via the Pass Track mobile application within 48 hours before arrival. Official may require passengers to undergo on -arrival rapid antigen testing (RAT). Symptomatic passengers and those who test positive must quarantine at designated sites until additional test returns a negative result. Passengers from category B countries who obtain a negative result from the on-arrival RAT must quarantine at designated facilities for 10 days, and can leave the premises only after getting a negative result from an RT-PCR test. Land border crossings with India and Iran remain closed, except for limited cargo transport. Authorities allow most border crossings with Afghanistan to operate, though Pakistani officials may require Afghan nationals above the age of 12 to produce a negative result from COVID-19 PCR test taken within 96 hours before arrival. Source: Garda World  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109174844/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/552861/pakistan-authorities-suspend-most-travel-from-additional-international-locations-as-of-dec-6-update-63

As of January,05,2022, the Pakistani government has modified its international travel rules. Categorical classification of countries is no longer valid, effectively lifting travel bans from category C locations, including several African and European countries, and Hong Kong among others. Revised rules mandate inbound passengers to hold proof of completing vaccination if above 18 years old and negative results of a PCR test obtained within 48 hours before departure if older than six years. They must continue to submit a health declaration from online or via the Pass Track mobile application within 48 hours before arrival. Returning Pakistani citizens unable to avail of vaccination due to visa or medical issues, as well as Afghan citizens entering via land borders, are exempt from carrying vaccination certificate. Passengers arriving via direct flights from Europe will undergo an on arrival rapid antigen test (RAT); officials will also administer RAT to 50% of arrivals from Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the UAE, as well as a random selection of passengers from other countries. Passengers with positive RAT test results must quarantine for 10 days at a government or self-paid facility, those who test positive on the mandatory PCR test on the eighth day must undergo additional quarantine until they return negative result in a PCR test. Source: Garda World  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109175054/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/562991/pakistan-authorities-lift-travel-bans-modify-entry-testing-restrictions-as-of-jan-5-update-64

No change in policy since June,2021. Provincial governments implemented supportive fiscal measures including cash grants to low-income households, tax relief, and additional health spending (including a salary increase for healthcare workers). The government of Punjab implemented a PKR 18 billion tax relief package and a PKR 10 billion cash grants program. The government of Sindh's measures included cash grant and ration distribution program of PKR 1.5 billion for low-income households. The FY 2021 provincial budgets also provided tax relaxations and sizeable increases in expenditure allocations, especially on health services. Source: International Monetary fund: Policy response to COVID-19 & International Growth Centre; COVID-19 policy response dashboard  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220107215142/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220107233238/https://www.theigc.org/covid-19/tracker/

No change in policy since June,2021. Source: International Monetary fund: Policy response to COVID-19 & International Growth Centre; COVID-19 policy response dashboard   Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220107215142/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220107233238/https://www.theigc.org/covid-19/tracker/
There is a website dedicated to COVID-19 information.   Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109204353/https://covid.gov.pk/covid19

Testing is available both to individuals with symptoms as well as for asymptomatic individuals who need test for administrative reasons such as for pre-flight. Source: US embassy in Pakistan  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109190300/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Passengers arrive at Pakistan are required to download the Pass Track mobile app or provide their contact information through a web-based form. Source: US embassy in Pakistan  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220109190300/https://pk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to the most recent guidelines published in the ministry of health website, facemasks are mandatory to be worn by everyone whenever leaving their homes at all times including when at crowded public places, mosques, bazaars, shopping malls, public transport i.e. roads, rails, and flights. Source: Government of Pakistan COVID-19 website  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220110192316/https://storage.covid.gov.pk/new_guidelines/11December2020_20201211_Guidelines_for_mandatory_use_of_face_mask_1705.pdf

All citizen 12+ years old are eligible to receive COVID-19 vaccines. For boosters shot eligibility criteria as follows:  1.	Immunocompromised persons of all eligible age groups  2.	Citizen, 30 years of age and above  3.	Healthcare workers.  For age group 12-18 years old only Pfizer vaccine is administered.   Available vaccines are Sinopharm, Sinovac, Pfizer and Moderna.   Vaccine is free for unvaccinated.  Source: Government of Pakistan National Command Operating Centre  Archived link: https://web.archive.org/web/20220110155852/https://ncoc.gov.pk/covid-vaccination-en.php
